Description: Terracotta figure of Harpocratis riding a ram. Harpocratis seated on a ram which stands to the right on a plain-faced plinth. She is dressed in a long tunic with short sleeves: her feminine body is indicated below her clothing. She wears a round pendant on a ribbon round her neck and there is a bracelet on her right wrist. Her finger is to her mouth and she has an overflowing cornucopia held against her left shoulder. She has a full head of hair, with a topknot, and wears a large wreath with a tightly woven element surrounded by vineleaves; the wreath is surmounted by a Double Crown. The back is plain except for a circular vent. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with minute traces of a white dressing on the front; a little pink paint survives on the tunic.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Bibliog. Higgins 1967: pl. 63c; Fischer 1994: 279, no. 622. Note: Previously considered to be Romano-Egyptian, 1stC to 2ndC.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3084)
Condition: A hole is broken through the front between the ram’s legs; the plinth is chipped at the back.
